channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Russia Presses Attacks as U.S. Sees Tension in Kremlin
item.description: The U.S. and its allies were skeptical of Moscow’s pledge to scale back its offensive, as fighting raged on. President Biden was mulling tapping U.S. oil reserves, as American officials said Vladimir Putin had been misled by his aides.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents walking past destroyed buildings in Trostyanets, Ukraine, on Wednesday, after the Ukrainian Army recaptured the town.

item.title: Myanmar Is Still at War, More Than a Year After Military Coup
item.description: Fleeing the military’s brutal crackdown, Myanmar’s newest rebels have abandoned cafes and professions to join a near-daily battle with long odds.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Adam Dean
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: A former banquet coordinator for a hotel in Yangon, at right, is among the rebel militia fighters battling Myanmar’s military in the jungles and hills of Kayin State.

item.title: ‘Like Living in a Horror Movie’: A Ukraine Town Dying a Slow Death
item.description: The war never stops in Huliaipole, a town on the front lines in eastern Ukraine. Most residents have fled. Those who remain listen to the Russian shelling and wonder: Where will the next one land?
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

item.title: Jonathan Vance Pleads Guilty to Obstruction of Justice
item.description: The investigation that led to charges against Jonathan Vance, a former chief of Canada’s defense staff, is one of several that have ensnared current and former Canadian military commanders.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Gen. Jonathan Vance speaking in Ottawa in 2020.

item.title: Serbia Sticks With Russia, Bound by a Sense of Victimhood
item.description: Moscow, despite its invasion of Ukraine, remains a lodestar for nations like Serbia that feel resentment and grievance against the West, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of the pro-Russian political party Dveri during an election campaign rally in Belgrade.

item.title: In Life, They Showed Israel’s Breadth. In Death, They Were Victims.
item.description: The five victims of Israel’s deadliest terrorist attack in years came from different walks of life, highlighting the complexity of Israeli society.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Gabby Sobelman and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of Bnei Brak lit memorial candles Wednesday at the site of the shooting, Israel’s worst terrorist attack in eight years.

item.title: Putin’s War Is Complicating India’s Middle Path Among Powers
item.description: India has been reluctant to criticize Russia, long an important ally. But China’s rise, and its closeness to Vladimir Putin, is creating new pressure.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: From left, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, President Xi Jinping of China and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the BRICS summit in Brasilia, Brazil, in 2019.

item.title: Nigerians Mourn Victims of Deadly Train Attack
item.description: An attack by gunmen on a popular train route connecting Nigeria’s capital, Abuja, to a regional hub in the north, has left many with a growing feeling of insecurity.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Ben Ezeamalu
item.media:description: The then newly completed Abuja-Kaduna night railway line in Abuja, Nigeria, in 2016.

item.title: Bangladesh Sentences 4 to Death for Blogger’s Murder
item.description: The victim, who had promoted secularism, was among several writers fatally attacked in the country in 2015.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat
item.media:description: A rally in Dhaka, Bangladesh, in November 2015 to protest a series of deadly attacks on bloggers and publishers.

item.title: Warring Parties in Yemen Announce Overlapping Cease-Fires
item.description: Both the Saudi-led coalition and the Houthi rebels said they would stop fighting, but further progress toward an end to the seven-year war in the country was uncertain.
item.dc:creator: Shuaib Almosawa and Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Houthi rebels in Yemen marching through the capital, Sana, on Tuesday. The war has killed tens of thousands of people inside the country and caused a humanitarian catastrophe.

item.title: U.S. Pressured to Open Consulates in Jerusalem and Western Sahara
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, on travels through the Middle East and North Africa over the past week, was urged by Arab leaders to make good on past promises.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Aida Alami
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, center right, with Foreign Minister Nasser Bourita of Morocco upon his arrival in Rabat, Morocco, on Monday.

item.title: Opposition Gets Key Vote to Oust Imran Khan
item.description: Without the support of Muttahida Qaumi Movement-Pakistan, the country’s prime minister will lose the simple majority needed to survive Parliament’s no-confidence vote.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum

item.title: How the Ukraine War Gave Fracking in the U.K. a Second Chance
item.description: Russia’s invasion has disrupted the global energy market and led to higher prices across Europe. That has reopened the debate in Britain over shale gas extraction.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A disused flare stack, left, at the Quadrilla fracking site in Little Plumpton, in Lancashire, northwestern England.

item.title: U.K. Judges Quit Top Hong Kong Court
item.description: They had served on the territory’s highest court, part of an arrangement to retain links to the common law world after Hong Kong returned to China.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: The Court of Final Appeal in Hong Kong on Wednesday. The resignations will add to questions about the autonomy of Hong Kong’s judiciary.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Russian attacks on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers fortifying the Princess Olga monument in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Russia Steps Up Attacks Amid Reports of Rifts in Moscow
item.description: Despite claims of de-escalation, Russian forces turned their fury on Chernihiv and the suburbs of Kyiv. U.S. officials say they believe Vladimir Putin’s aides are misleading him about the war.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Megan Specia and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers using sandbags to fortify the Princess Olga Monument in Kyiv on Wednesday.

item.title: President Dissolves Tunisia’s Parliament, Deepening Political Crisis
item.description: President Kais Saied, who suspended Parliament last year, dismissed that body after lawmakers challenged the autocratic powers he has exercised.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: President Kais Saied of Tunisia taking the oath of office in Tunis, in 2019.

item.title: Putin’s Advisers Misinformed Him on Ukraine, U.S. Intelligence Suggests
item.description: One American official said that there “is now persistent tension” between the Russian president and his Defense Ministry.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Lara Jakes and John Ismay
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukranian soldiers inspecting a damaged Russian military vehicle in Irpin, a suburb of Kyiv, the capital, on Tuesday.

item.title: Flamingo Spotted in Texas After Escaping a Kansas Zoo in 2005
item.description: A fisherman’s sighting in March confirmed that a flamingo that fled a Kansas zoo in 2005 has defied the odds to live a Pixar-worthy life in the wilds of Texas.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: No. 492, an African flamingo that escaped from the Sedgwick County Zoo in Kansas in 2005, was seen in Calhoun County, Texas, in 2019. A Texas fisherman spotted the bird again this month.

item.title: Russian Negotiator’s Optimism Clashes with Moscow’s Rhetoric
item.description: The mixed messages underscored the lack of clarity over President Vladimir V. Putin’s goals in the invasion.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fighting and shelling has continued in and around Kyiv as mixed messages about the results of diplomatic talks have emerged from the Kremlin and Russia’s negotiators.

item.title: How Your Sense of Direction Is Shaped by Where You Grew Up
item.description: Childhood environments shape people’s navigational skills, researchers reported. The findings one day may lead to better tests for early dementia.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: Researchers found that people who grow up in predictable, gridlike cities like Manhattan seem to struggle with directions more than those from more rural areas or more intricate cities.

item.title: German Authorities Warn Fleeing Ukrainians to Look Out for Thieves
item.description: The federal police in Berlin have sent additional units to the city’s main train station to help safeguard fleeing Ukrainians, who are mostly women and children.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Maryna Galla, center, and her son, Daniil, waited for a train at Berlin Central Station after arriving last week in Germany from Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: Ruble Shows Signs of Recovery, but May Not Be Strong Indicator of Economy
item.description: The ruble’s stronger showing is most likely driven by artificial factors and might not be a good marker that the Russian economy is improving, one expert said.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko

item.title: Satellite Images Show Food Lines in Mariupol, Ukraine
item.description: The city has been under siege for weeks and is suffering from severe food and water shortages.
item.dc:creator: Haley Willis and Sarah Kerr
item.media:description: A satellite image captured by Maxar Technologies on Tuesday shows hundreds of people lined up outside of a supermarket in Mariupol.

item.title: After Russia Invaded Ukraine, a U.S. Nonprofit Shifted Its Mission
item.description: Spirit of America was focused on helping counter Russian propaganda but now is sending helmets, Kevlar vests, radios and vehicles to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jim Hake, founder and CEO of Spirit of America, in front of supplies his organization is sending to Ukraine.

item.title: A Mural Celebrating Tipu Sultan Sold at Auction. His Legacy Is Contested.
item.description: The battle scene depicts a victory over British troops by an 18th-century Muslim, a man India’s current government would prefer was forgotten.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: An early 19th-century depiction of the Battle of Pollilur on view at Sotheby’s in London this week.

item.title: Family’s Balcony Death in Switzerland Appears to Be Suicide
item.description: The investigation suggests that the victims jumped from the seventh-floor balcony “one after the other,” the police said.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The building in Montreux, Switzerland, from which five members of a French family apparently jumped off last week.

item.title: The Battle for Donbas
item.description: Russia appears to be focusing more on eastern Ukraine. That’s both good and bad for Ukraine’s military.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A shelter in Lviv.

item.title: How War in Ukraine Roiled Facebook and Instagram
item.description: The rules over what war content is permitted on Facebook and Instagram keep changing, causing internal confusion.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac, Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Peace talks between Russia and Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fighters of the Ukrainian Odin Unit, including foreign volunteers, among them Americans and Britons, in Irpin, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Sanctioned Oligarch’s Presence Adds Intrigue to Ukraine-Russia Talks
item.description: Roman Abramovich, sanctioned owner of the Chelsea Football Club, mysteriously showed up at the talks between Ukraine and Russia in Istanbul, and is said to be playing an unofficial role.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Roman Abramovich, the Russian oligarch who owns the Chelsea Football Club, center-rear, during peace talks in Istanbul, in an image from video provided by the Turkish president’s office, on Tuesday.

item.title: Ukrainian Military Fends Off Russia and Retakes Suburb of Kyiv
item.description: Ukrainian soldiers have essentially retaken, for now, the town of Irpin, the scene of fierce fighting in recent weeks. Its success shows the steep challenges Russia faces in trying to capture Ukraine’s capital.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian fighters of the Odin Unit, including some foreign fighters from the United States and Britain, waiting to advance during a clearing-out operation of remaining Russian forces on Tuesday in Irpin, Ukraine.

item.title: Peace Talks May Be Little More Than Russian Tactics, Analysts Say
item.description: As signs of progress emerged during the peace talks, some saw them as Russia buying time to regroup its military forces before another offensive push in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Murat Cetin Muhurdar/Turkish Presidential Press Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey during the Ukrainian-Russian talks in Istanbul on Tuesday.

item.title: The Fighters Who Took Over a Retail Store to Defend Kyiv
item.description: As Russia pledges to scale back operations in Kyiv, soldiers from the 112th Brigade of Ukraine’s Territorial Defense Forces are still preparing for the worst. Our cameras went inside their makeshift base.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Brent McDonald, Mark Boyer and Benjamin Foley
item.media:credit: Benjamin Foley for The New York Times

item.title: Russia-Ukraine Peace Talks Signal Progress, but No End to War Is in Sight
item.description: Russia said it would “drastically” reduce military activity around Kyiv, while Ukraine said it would be willing to accept neutrality and discuss territorial claims to resolve the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fighters of the Ukrainian Odin Unit, including foreign volunteers, among them Americans and Britons, in Irpin, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: A Vow to Ease Bombing Is Too Late for Many in Ukraine City Near Kyiv
item.description: Russia’s offer, if honored, will not help the thousands who have already fled Chernihiv.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iryna Shepetova escaped from Chernihiv with her three children and her mother on one of the last minibuses out of the city last week, as Russian forces were closing in.

item.title: BA.2 Accounts for Over Half of New U.S. Cases, C.D.C. Estimates
item.description: Scientists have been keeping an eye on BA.2, one of three genetically distinct varieties of the Omicron variant of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Administering a coronavirus test at a drive-through testing site in Hagerstown, Md., last month.

item.title: Russia-Ukraine Peace Talks Enter a New Phase in Istanbul
item.description: “All the world is expecting good news from you,” President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said in greeting the Russian and Ukrainian delegations.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Murat Cetin Muhurdar/Turkish Presidential Press Service, via AFP – Getty Images
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey speaking on Tuesday before talks between Ukrainian and Russian negotiators in Istanbul, in a photo provided by the Turkish presidential press service.

item.title: Britain Seizez Russian Superyacht
item.description: The British authorities have joined those nations putting pressure on Vladimir Putin by targeting the assets of his wealthy supporters.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The Russian-owned superyacht Phi seized by Britain on Tuesday.

item.title: Palestinian Gunman Kills 5 in Israel’s Fifth Attack in Recent Days
item.description: The attack in a Tel Aviv suburb brought the number of people killed in the past two weeks to 11, making it one of the deadliest periods in Israel in several years.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Gabby Sobelman
item.media:description: Israeli security and medical personnel at the scene of an attack in Bnei Brak, near Tel Aviv, Israel, on Tuesday.

item.title: Accounts of Russian Rapes Are Growing, Ukraine Officials Say
item.description: A Ukrainian woman’s account of being repeatedly raped was published in The Times of London, and a member of Ukraine’s Parliament said there were “many more” such assaults.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: Marina Goldovskaya, 80, Dies; Filmmaker Documented Russian Life
item.description: In about 30 documentaries she looked at the people and history of her homeland, some of it brutally dark.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Ramsey

item.title: Prince Andrew, Banished From Royal Duties, Escorts Queen to Memorial
item.description: The prince’s conspicuous public appearance at the service for his father, Prince Philip, who died last year, sent an unmistakable message of support by a 95-year-old mother for her disgraced son.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Britain’s Queen Elizabeth, accompanied by Prince Andrew, Duke of York, attending a service of thanksgiving for late Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, at Westminster Abbey in London, Britain, on Tuesday.

item.title: Gunmen Attack Train Near Nigerian Capital, Killing Some Riders
item.description: The attackers used explosives to blow up the rail track before opening fire on the train in the latest in a series of train assaults.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Mariupol Residents Describe How Russian Forces Deprived Them of Food and Water
item.description: Residents of Mariupol, Ukraine, described how they are surviving a monthlong siege of the southern port with little food and other necessities. “No roof, no food and no water,” survivors texted relatives.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Ben Hubbard and Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yulia Beley, center, with her daughter and friends from Mariupol at a shelter in Lviv, western Ukraine.

item.title: Women Drive Germany’s Foreign Policy Shift Amid Ukraine War
item.description: Angela Merkel is no longer chancellor. But as war rages in Ukraine, a mere 10-hour drive from Berlin, female ministers oversee national security.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Christine Lambrecht, the German defense minister, visiting the Ninth Panzerlehr Brigade of the armed forces, in Münster, Germany, in February.

item.title: Could the U.S. do More for Ukraine?
item.description: President Biden says that Ukraine has the full support of the U.S. Volodymyr Zelensky disagrees.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oleg, 61, in Kyiv, after being shot in the leg by Russian forces.

item.title: Desperate for Cash, Afghans Toil in Mines That Are Deadlier Than Ever
item.description: Faced with life-threatening hunger, thousands labor in the coal mines of Baghlan. But safety measures that the former government once provided are gone.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Yaqoob Akbary and Jim Huylebroek
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times

item.title: Farhana Yamin’s Journey From Climate Summits to Street Protests
item.description: After a high-profile career as an international lawyer and negotiator, Farhana Yamin decided “we cannot rely on lawyers and diplomats alone.”
item.dc:creator: Mélissa Godin
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Farhana Yamin, one of the architects of the Paris climate agreement, at a protest in London in 2019.

item.title: Shanghai’s Lockdown Tests Covid-Zero Policy, and People’s Limits
item.description: A staggered lockdown on China’s commercial capital of 26 million people has sent beleaguered residents scrambling and raised fears of broader damage to the economy.
item.dc:creator: John Liu and Paul Mozur
item.media:description: A worker in protective gear received food from a delivery man while guarding the entrance to a neighborhood under lockdown in Shanghai on Tuesday.

item.title: London Police Issue Fines for Downing Street Lockdown Parties
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson was not among those penalized, his office said, but the police decision puts a perilous political scandal back in the spotlight.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain leaving Downing Street in London last week. He has steadfastly denied that he violated any lockdown rules.

item.title: Solomon Islands’ Leader Calls Concern Over China Security Deal ‘Insulting’
item.description: Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare criticized Australia and New Zealand as assuming that the island nation could not act in its own best interests.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare, left, of the Solomon Islands met with the Chinese premier, Li Keqiang, in Beijing in 2019.

item.title: A Brutal Russian Playbook Reapplied in Ukraine
item.description: The besieging of cities, the deliberate targeting of civilians — they are the tactics Russia used before, in Grozny. I saw it firsthand.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Ukraine reports some battle successes.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Damaged Russian tank in the town of Trostyanets, east of capital Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Coronavirus deaths in the U.S. fall to their lowest point since the summer.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: People visiting the cherry blossoms in Washington on Friday. New Covid-19 cases are rising in the nation’s capital.

item.title: Biden Says of Condemning Putin: ‘I Make No Apologies’
item.description: President Biden said his words, delivered in a speech over the weekend in Warsaw, were not a call for regime change in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Leigh Vogel for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden announcing his budget for Fiscal Year 2023, which reduces deficits by more than $1 trillion over the next decade, in the White House on Monday.
